Title.evidence: The study used a randomised, double‐blind, sham‐controlled crossover design.

Trial_Design.evidence: The study used a randomised, double‐blind, sham‐controlled crossover design.

Participants.evidence: Eight participants spent counterbalanced normoxic and hypoxic weeks in a residential hypoxia facility.

Intervention.evidence: Eight participants spent counterbalanced normoxic and hypoxic weeks in a residential hypoxia facility and underwent repeated cardiopulmonary exercise tests.

Objective.evidence: We aimed to provide an initial physiological foundation for ‘altitude prehabilitation’ by determining the physiological effects of one week of simulated altitude.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: The study used a randomised, double‐blind, sham‐controlled crossover design.

Blinding.evidence: The study used a randomised, double‐blind, sham‐controlled crossover design.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Eight participants spent counterbalanced normoxic and hypoxic weeks.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Hypoxia induced a substantial increase in mean (SD) haemoglobin of 1.5 (2.7) g.dl ‐1 (13% increase, p = 0.028).

Harms.evidence: Hypoxia was mild (mean (SD) S p O 2 93 (2) %, p < 0.001) and well‐tolerated.
